title: Understanding Spontaneity in Reactions
text: To determine if a reaction is spontaneous, we need to calculate the Gibbs Free Energy Change (ΔG). The sign of ΔG will tell us whether the reaction is spontaneous $$(-)$$ or not (+).

title: Formula for Gibbs Free Energy
text:
Recall the formula for Gibbs Free Energy change:
ΔG $$=$$ ΔH - T × ΔS
Where:
- ΔH is the enthalpy change $$(-92.4$$ kJ/mol),
- ΔS is the entropy change $$(-198.3$$ J/mol·K),
- T is the temperature in Kelvin.

title: Finding the Temperature for Spontaneity
text:
For the reaction to be spontaneous, ΔG must be negative. Therefore, set the inequality:
ΔG < $$0$$
This implies:
ΔH - T × ΔS < $$0$$

title: Solving for Temperature (T)
text: Solve the inequality:\nΔH - T × ΔS < $$0$$\nBy rearranging the terms, find the temperature T for which the reaction becomes spontaneous.

title: Calculation Verification
text:
Plug the given values into the inequality:
- Convert ΔH from kJ to J (ΔH $$=$$ $$-92400$$ J/mol)
- ΔS $$=$$ $$-198.3$$ $$ rac{J}{mol·K}$$
- Solve for T:
$$(-92400)$$ - T × $$(-198.3)$$ < $$0$$
Simplify to find the critical temperature.

title: Final Answer Interpretation
text:
Based on the calculations, determine if the answer aligns with the multiple choice answers:
A. Spontaneous at T < $$466$$ K
B. Spontaneous at T > $$466$$ K
C. Spontaneous at T $$=$$ $$466$$ K
D. Non-spontaneous at any temperature
